required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Mechanical Versus Manual Chest Compression: A Retrospective Study in Out-of-hospital Cardiac Arrest

brief_summary.textblock: In this study, the investigators compared mechanical and manual chest compressions in out-of-hospital cardiac arrest cases.

detailed_description.textblock: In this study, the investigators retrospectively analyzed resuscitations performed over a 2-year period and compared manual and mechanical chest compressions in terms of return of spontaneous circulation, 30-day survival, and hospital discharge parameters.

primary_outcome.measure: Rate of the mortality on the 30th day
primary_outcome.description: Mortality from the admission to the 30th day

primary_outcome.measure: Rate of the return of spontaneous circulation
primary_outcome.description: Return of spontaneous circulation at least 5 minutes

arm_group.description: Manuel chest compressions will be handled by human efforts.
In the study, chest compression in the mechanical cardiopulmonary resuscitation group was performed with the Lund University Cardiopulmonary Assist System (LUCAS) Chest Compression System (LUCAS 2).

intervention.description: LUCAS is a portable device designed to rule out the problems encountered during manual chest compression, capable of performing standard and continuous chest compressions at a depth of 4-5 cm and at least 100 times per minute.

intervention.intervention_name: Manuel chest compressions by human efforts
intervention.description: In this way chest compressions will be handled by humans themselves.

study_pop.textblock: The data of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest cases undergoing cardiopulmonary resuscitation in the emergency department were analyzed retrospectively.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Over 18 age Cardiac arrest cases Out-of-hospital arrest
Exclusion Criteria:
<18 age

facility.name: Ankara Yıldırım Beyazıt University, School of Medicine, Department of Emergency Medicine

reference.citation: Brodal Syversen K, Souvannasacd E, Renger R. Validating the LUCAS® mechanical chest compression fit specifications. Am J Emerg Med. 2019 Feb;37(2):371-373. doi: 10.1016/j.ajem.2018.06.069. Epub 2018 Jun 30.

Bonnes JL, Brouwer MA, Navarese EP, Verhaert DV, Verheugt FW, Smeets JL, de Boer MJ. Manual Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation Versus CPR Including a Mechanical Chest Compression Device in Out-of-Hospital Cardiac Arrest: A Comprehensive Meta-analysis From Randomized and Observational Studies. Ann Emerg Med. 2016 Mar;67(3):349-360.e3. doi: 10.1016/j.annemergmed.2015.09.023. Epub 2015 Nov 19. Review.

Gates S, Quinn T, Deakin CD, Blair L, Couper K, Perkins GD. Mechanical chest compression for out of hospital cardiac arrest: Systematic review and meta-analysis. Resuscitation. 2015 Sep;94:91-7. doi: 10.1016/j.resuscitation.2015.07.002. Epub 2015 Jul 17. Review.

patient_data.ipd_description: There is no plan to share individual participant data (IPD) with other researchers.
